risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Companion Animal Euthanasia Training Academy, Lutz, FL, USA

sect2.title: 11.1 Introduction
sect2.para: The title “Anatomy of a humane euthanasia” represents the complexities that go into performing this very important medical procedure. There are many moving parts, all layered upon each other to create a transformative experience, not only for the patient but also for the caregiver and veterinary team. Each element supports the next, ultimately culminating in the death of the patient. This is why the veterinary team was hired: to relieve suffering and to do so in the safest, smoothest, and gentlest way possible.

Euthanasia may be described as humanely terminating life and this phrasing is often included in euthanasia consent forms. With attention to each element of euthanasia, the patient is given a humane death that meets a goal many people want for themselves: to die peacefully in their sleep [ch0023-c11-bib-0001, ch0023-c11-bib-0002]. The word “humane” has become somewhat of a catchall term meaning to show kindness, care, and empathy, especially to those who are suffering. All veterinary technicians have the opportunity to implement the 14 Essential Components of Companion Animal Euthanasia listed in Chapter 10. Embracing these components while also holding a deeper understanding of how euthanasia methods work is the purpose of this chapter. A technician’s approach to euthanasia says a lot about their commitment to patient care and the preservation of animals’ dignity through the last breath of life.

sect2.title: 11.2 Technicians as Euthanasia Attendants
sect2.para: There are many moving parts to a successful euthanasia appointment in the veterinary hospital, and technicians can manage most if not all of them. As euthanasia is such an emotional experience for caregivers, it is helpful to have one technician designated to be with them for the duration of the appointment. This technician is known as the euthanasia attendant for that caregiver and patient. They greet the caregiver and patient when they arrive and direct them into the hospital and to the euthanasia room. They review the paperwork, finalize aftercare choices, and describe the procedure. Caregivers may need water, facial tissue, bathroom breaks, and other comforts, which can all be provided by their designated technician. Throughout the appointment, many staff members may come and go from the room, but the euthanasia attendant is always there addressing the needs of the family until euthanasia is complete. They may walk grieving caregivers out to their vehicles and ensure a safe departure, follow up with a phone call the next day, and send a sympathy card.

In many cases, the technician already knows the family, having worked with them in wellness appointments, or during palliative care treatments and hospice support. These relationships increase the bond during euthanasia and should lead to more trust and safety felt by all parties. In the case of home euthanasia, it is likely the veterinarian and technician are there for the entirety of the appointment, and therefore both will act as attendants.

sect2.title: 11.3 Euthanasia Methods and the Physiology of Death
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians are substantially more prepared for end‐of‐life (EOL) work when they understand the cascade of events that leads to the death of their patient, whether it’s natural death or through euthanasia. With greater understanding, technicians are able to not only predict what’s coming next in the dying trajectory but also better explain to caregivers what is happening and why. Death is a significant life event. Knowledge reduces fear and hopefully increases a comfortable familiarity with what is occurring.

Before euthanasia, dying animal patients have already begun a series of cellular and organ changes leading to death. This is because as the body ages, the heart weakens and reduces its ability to adequately oxygenate tissues. Euthanasia is an abridged version of this where the method eventually or directly stops the heart from beating, and blood ceases to circulate throughout the body. Without blood flow, there is no oxygen delivery to the brain and death becomes permanent. The heart, however, is not necessarily the primary facilitator of death. The brain holds the neurologic center for consciousness and life; therefore, many euthanasia methods specifically focus on brain cessation/death.

sect3.title: 11.3.1 Methods of Euthanasia
sect3.para: Euthanasia is achieved via three main methods, all with the goal of making death irreversible and permanent. The first is the direct depression of neurons necessary for life function. This occurs when pharmaceutical agents are given to the patient, by mouth, injection, or inhalation of anesthetic gases. In companion animal euthanasia, this first method is the most common and will likely remain so for many years to come. Simply administering a drug/agent to quietly end life is desirable. Examples of this include the administration of a lethal dose of pentobarbital, T61®, magnesium sulfate, or lidocaine. These agents work on the brain to cease all life functions, and the body shuts down concurrently. Pentobarbital, a very common euthanasia agent, is known to first cause brain death, then stop respiration (apnea), and lastly stop the heart (asystole). This cascade of events guarantees the patient is unconscious when cardiac arrest occurs.

The second method to achieve death is through hypoxia. This means the body’s tissues, in particular the heart and brain, are quickly deprived of life‐sustaining oxygen. The method targets the cessation of blood flow throughout the body. Example methods include the administration of potassium chloride to directly stop the heart, or exsanguination to drain the body of blood. Neither is common in companion animal euthanasia, but nevertheless can be done if the veterinarian feels the technique is appropriate to the situation.

The third method is to physically damage the brain, especially the brain stem. Examples of this include gunshots, captive bolts, and pithing, which uses a rod inserted into the brain to destroy brain tissue. These methods may sound harsher than the others; however, they play an important role when the first two methods are not appropriate or possible. Physical methods such as pithing are often secondary euthanasia methods in reptiles to ensure death is irreversible ch0023-c11-bib-0003.

sect3.title: 11.3.2 Body Changes
sect3.para: The body changes that occur at death can be categorized by when they take place in the dying process, be it through hospice‐supported natural death or euthanasia.

listitem.para: Antemortem: before death
Perimortem: during death
Postmortem: after death

sect3.para: Bodily changes at death are expected to be seen and sometimes heard or even smelled. The five perimortem changes that get the most attention are vocalization, agonal breathing, opisthotonos stretching, myoclonic muscle twitches, and bodily fluid release. These five signs are readily visible to the caregiver and can cause concern that perhaps their pet is struggling with death in some way, however, they are normal and expected. All visible body changes can happen regardless of the manner of death, whether through euthanasia or a natural passing. Postmortem changes will be explained in more detail inChapter 13.
Perimortem changes may include any of the following:

listitem.para: Vocalization (sounds such as whining or moaning): Vocalization is extremely rare, especially when the pet is already asleep or unconscious, but it does happen from time to time with various species. Depending on the euthanasia method, it may occur during stage 1 or stage 2 of anesthesia when overdoses of anesthetic drugs are used, or completely involuntarily during physical methods. The occasional exhale may vibrate vocal cords and give off sound. Without question, vocalization during death is upsetting to caregivers ch0023-c11-bib-0004.

Agonal breathing (a brainstem reflex specific to death): Agonal breaths do not bring oxygen into the body but rather are simply respiratory‐looking movements that are nonproductive. It is the start of apnea (no breathing). They are triggered by low oxygen flow and acidemia in the brainstem. To the observer, they mimic gasping for air and attempting to breathe. Instead, agonal breaths are evidence that the brain is dying and there is no conscious perception by the patient that these gasping movements are occurring. Agonal breaths can last a few seconds or a few hours ch0023-c11-bib-0005; however, in this author’s experience, companion animals typically take one to ten agonal breaths in total. Once they begin, this natural reflex will continue until done. Patient pre‐euthanasia anesthesia/unconsciousness may reduce the likelihood of agonal breathing ch0023-c11-bib-0006.

Opisthotonos stretching (a large body stretch caused by a spasm of the axial muscles along the spinal column): The term originates from the Greek language meaning “behind tension.” It’s a state of severe hyperextension and spasticity in which a pet’s head and neck arch backward ch0023-c11-bib-0007. The legs will usually stretch out and the tail will curl up over the back (see Figure 11.1). What triggers this spasm is questionable, but it can be reproduced experimentally by damaging the midbrain. This odd posturing can be seen with tetanus infections and hydrocephalus cases as well. The caregiver may be surprised by such a large movement and should be informed about the possibility. Opisthotonos stretches are often followed by agonal breathing.

Figure 11.1

textobject.phrase: A dog lies on a soft surface, with its body stretched out and legs extended, showcasing its fluffy fur and relaxed posture.

listitem.para: Myoclonic twitches (sudden, brief, shock‐like movements caused by muscle contractions (positive myoclonus) or inhibitions (negative myoclonus)) ch0023-c11-bib-0008: Myoclonic twitches look like muscle fasciculations in various parts of the patient’s body. They can be small or large movements, even appearing like minor limb kicking. They can be seen in patients during the antemortem, perimortem, and postmortem phases of death. Myoclonic twitches after death give the appearance that the patient may still be living, however they are not. Caregivers may be reassured that it is normal and nothing to be concerned about.

Bodily fluid release (urination and defecation occur when sphincter tone is absent, and both are common during death): Caregivers may expect this to happen and prepare potty pads/towels, although keeping the body and surroundings clean and dry is usually the job of the veterinarian or technician. Other bodily fluids include oral and nasal discharge (blood, thoracic effusion) from the respiratory system or vomitus from the stomach. The head can be slightly elevated to keep fluid inside.

sect3.para: Other physical changes can be seen during and just after death including pupil dilation, corneal glazing, lack of reflexes, and piloerection (hairs raising up). They are further examples to the veterinary team and caregiver that the body is no longer alive. Eye changes can be particularly difficult for caregivers because they become dry and “lifeless” very quickly. The eyelids often remain open meaning the eye changes are highly visible. This is usually a stark contrast to the way they were in life. Another physical change, albeit rare, is an increase in external parasite activity. Observers may find fleas and mites rise to the surface seeking to find another warm body. This author once witnessed nasal mites exiting the nostrils of a dog during euthanasia with pentobarbital. As the dog exhaled fumes from the circulating pentobarbital in the blood, the mites quickly escaped.

A quiet body during death will be viewed as more peaceful. Caregivers appreciate this and it is one of the reasons why pre‐euthanasia sleep is so desired. Sedatives and anesthetics can be given to patients to induce light or deep sleep before the euthanasia method is carried out. Ideally, the sleeping patient has a death free of movements such as the ones listed above, although in this author’s experience, it becomes an opportunity to demonstrate that death is occurring at the exact moment these perimortem events happen. It removes uncertainties that the pet may still be living, and that euthanasia was unsuccessful.

sect2.title: 11.4 Pre‐euthanasia Sedation and Anesthesia Protocols
sect2.para: Modern‐day euthanasia of companion animals includes patient sleep during death. Patients are provided with pre‐euthanasia sedatives and/or anesthetics to reduce pain and anxiety during the procedure and ideally facilitate deep sleep, so the patient is unaware of the process. In 2013, the American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA) Guidelines for the Euthanasia of Animals stated that the use of pre‐euthanasia sedation or anesthesia should be provided whenever practical, especially with companion animalsch0023-c11-bib-0009. This was a significant change from other versions of the guidelines and was evidence that sleep before death was gaining momentum. Other groups such as the American Animal Hospital Association (AAHA) and Fear Free® Program soon followed with a similar message. Today, especially in animal hospice euthanasia, this approach is expected by both the veterinary team and caregivers.

Inducing a sleep‐like state should be considered when euthanizing companion animals in the presence of loved ones. Every veterinary team will have preferred drug protocols, which should always be adjusted to meet the individual needs of the patient yet standardized so that each one receives something before euthanasia. This means the patient is sleeping before the actual euthanasia method begins and helps to reduce the need for restraint for such things as intravenous (IV) catheter placement. If the patient already has an indwelling IV catheter placed, it may be used to give drugs. Caregivers want their pets to be sleeping during euthanasia and believe this will help make for a more peaceful passingch0023-c11-bib-0004. The more veterinary teams use pre‐euthanasia drugs, the more familiar they will become with their effects and the better they will become at describing expected changes to caregivers. Caregivers may remain with their pets while they succumb to sleep, creating a calm environment ideally free of distractions and overstimulation.

Administering drugs to physically compromised patients has pros and cons, and both should be weighed before proceeding with administration. The best approach is to pay close attention to the patient’s signalment and the planned euthanasia technique.

listitem.para: Reduces fear and anxiety over handling during the euthanasia procedure
Allows for caregiver and patient closeness before death
Minimizes restraint during euthanasia itself
Relieves pain before death
Increases euthanasia technique options
May lead to physical distress in critical patients (e.g. dyspnea)
Can slow down time to death (i.e. longer appointment time)
Greater expense

sect2.para: Common drug classes used for sedation or anesthesia include alpha‐2 agonists, tranquilizers, opioids, benzodiazepines, and dissociatives such as ketamine. Typically, pre‐euthanasia sedatives and anesthetics are used in combination to synergistically deliver the smoothest results. It’s important to note that sedative and anesthetic drugs are not the same thing. A sedation protocol only contains sedative drugs while an anesthetic protocol only needs one anesthetic drug to be considered an anesthesia protocol. Sedation drugs may lead to deep sleep, but they cannot be relied upon to induce unconsciousness ch0023-c11-bib-0010 (see Figure 11.2). Patient unconsciousness requires the use of anesthetic drugs at proper doses to elicit stage 3 anesthesia (surgical depth) (see Figure 11.3). This is necessary before performing euthanasia methods known or believed to be painful.

sect2.para: Drugs can be administered via different routes including oral (PO), oral transmucosal (OTM), subcutaneous (SC), intramuscular (IM), IV, and inhalation.Table 11.1 lists some common drug types used in companion animal EOL patients.

Depending on the patient’s health status and signalment, it may be advisable to reach for an anesthetic protocol over a sedative. Patients who are high energy, nervous, dyspneic, aggressive, or in severe pain may resist sedation alone and require something stronger. With enough stimulation, patients can wake from sedation, increasing the risk of pain and further anxiety during the euthanasia procedure. Therefore, intra‐organ euthanasia methods, such as intracardiac injections, require complete unconsciousness from anesthetic drugs. The patient must be unaware that the injection is taking place.

sect3.title: 11.4.1 Effects of Pre‐euthanasia Sedation and Anesthesia Protocols
sect3.para: During the early stages of relaxation, patients can have a stuporous appearance, ataxia, and lick their lips. Their eyes often remain open. There is typically a change to the respiratory rate which varies from patient to patient. Caregivers expressing concern can be assured that breathing change is expected. Urination and defecation commonly occur after death, but if the pet is very deep in sleep, the body can release fluids before death. This makes it necessary for technicians to be proactive rather than reactive and protect the patient’s hind end with absorbent materials. Blood pressure changes are expected and acceptable but add to the complexity. It means venous access is more challenging and time to death may be slowed. Muscle fasciculations and/or twitching are acceptable but can alarm those in the room. Veterinarians will want to avoid drugs and protocols that elicit nausea and vomiting, especially in already critical patients; although even with the most careful planning, all these physical changes may still present. The technician’s role is to explain and manage any and all complexities brought on by the use of sedatives and anesthetics (Pro Tip 11.1). The goal is to standardize protocols for patients with pre‐existing conditions that will minimize these effects and also lead to a smooth, comfortable sleep.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 11.1 During Pre‐euthanasia Sedation or Anesthesia

listitem.para: Bring all drugs into the room with the patient and caregiver.
Determine the correct drug protocols and dosages based on patient signalment and planned euthanasia technique. Follow standardized protocols whenever possible.
Administer drugs in ways that reduce patient stress and pain. Ask the caregiver if their pet is painful anywhere before an injection is attempted.
If the patient needs more drugs to reach deep sedation or anesthesia, give more.
Test for complete unconsciousness before attempting a euthanasia technique that requires it.
Position absorbent material under the patient once they are sleeping.
Remain present in the room to address negative drug side effects and monitor for premature patient death.

It is possible for sedatives and anesthetics to cause death before the actual euthanasia method is carried out. This happens when the compromised body becomes so depressed by the drugs that the drugs themselves act as euthanasia agents. In this author’s experience, death via pre‐euthanasia sedatives and anesthetics is rare but it does happen. Technicians and veterinarians who are concerned about this possibility should discuss it with caregivers, so everyone is prepared if death comes sooner rather than later. They should also select drug doses that are suited to compromised patients. There is nothing inherently wrong with a patient being euthanized by pre‐euthanasia drugs, however, if it’s not planned, it can lead to rushed “goodbyes” before the caregiver is ready. Examples of euthanasia drug protocols can be found inTable 11.2.

sect3.title: 11.4.2 Administration of Pre‐euthanasia Sedation or Anesthesia
sect3.para: Injections under the skin or into the muscle can cause painful reactions. Technicians may ask caregivers if their pet is painful anywhere in the body that should be avoided. If an injection cannot be given without pain, oral or TM administration should be considered. Another option is to use what is referred to as a two‐step anesthesia protocol. This approach starts with the SC injection of neutral pH drugs such as butorphanol, acepromazine, and dexmedetomidine, which tend to elicit less reaction (see Figure 11.4). After 5–10 minutes of allowing these drugs to relax the patient, a second injection of lower pH drugs such as ketamine, midazolam, or tiletamine/zolazepam is given to induce complete anesthesia. This two‐step protocol is useful for all patients or those believed to be more sensitive to injections.

sect3.para: Many EOL patients can benefit from oral sedatives and anesthetics given in advance of the euthanasia appointment. Oral drugs may be fed or squirted into the mouth up to two hours before the appointment. The Chill Protocol, developed by Dr. Karas at the Cummings School of Veterinary Medicine at Tufts University, recommends some drugs be given the night before and the morning of the euthanasia appointmentch0023-c11-bib-0011. In this author’s experience, increasing oral sedative and anesthetic drug doses well above the normal limits is acceptable and even favorable during euthanasia, especially for aggressive patients.

It is important for caregivers to understand that oral sedatives and anesthetics will alter their pet’s mentation and behaviors right up until euthanasia. Technicians will want to be sensitive to this and encourage caregivers to create quiet, calm space around their pet, and to begin saying goodbye when the drugs are given. Once the pet is sleeping caregivers may feel a bit disconnected, therefore it is important that they are mentally prepared for these final moments. Sometimes the oral drugs do not make a significant impact and the patient remains awake. It is hard to predict which patients will fully succumb to the drugs and which ones won’t.

Regardless of how pre‐euthanasia drugs are administered, patient sleep and comfort will need to be assessed before proceeding with the euthanasia method. Euthanasia techniques that require patient unconsciousness (e.g. intra‐organ injections, IV potassium chloride, and T61 administration) require significant attempts to wake a patient before commencing. Unless the veterinary team has access to devices that measure brain activity, observing and feeling the patient’s body is the most practical approach. Breathing changes, muscle tension/relaxation, eye movements, and pain tolerance are what technicians will watch for. Patients that look unconscious need to be tested for any reactivity and most importantly, any pain. The goal in assessing a sleeping patient is to try to wake them. If they respond, they are still sensible and are not yet ready for a painful euthanasia method. However, they may be ready for a straightforward IV injection of pentobarbital.

emphasis.emphasis: Ways to Test for Unconsciousness in Patients Include

listitem.para: Give strong, significant pinches in between the toes and sensitive areas: ear flaps, inner thighs, and lips. Use fingernails to pinch extremely hard, mimicking what a hemostat clamp might do (seeFigure 11.5).
Check for abdominal muscle tensing. There should be no tensing of any muscles, including when the body is shifted or repositioned in preparation for the euthanasia injection.
Use clippers to shave legs for venous access. Patients should not lift their head or move their eyes when clippers are being used.
Raise the tail above the back. If unconscious, the patient will leave the tail where you place it rather than moving it down.

sect3.para: Technicians will do these tests subtly when caregivers are in the room. Caregivers will see their pet’s body being touched, but not in offensive or startling ways. In other words, pinching and testing for pain is a private affair. It takes a bit of finesse to make pinching look gentle, but it can be done. When the patient is ready, the euthanasia technique can begin. If they are not, technicians give more anesthetic drugs until they are. Reliable unconsciousness is worth waiting for (seeCommunication Corner 11.1).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 11.1 Patients Requiring More Time or Sedation
sidebar.para: Caregivers may express concern with the procedure taking longer than expected, or with their pet requiring repeated drug administrations. Gently let them know that you are simply listening to what their pet is telling you they need.
“If she needs more medicine to be ready, we’ll be patient and give what she needs. This is her day and we’ll all here for her.”

sect2.title: 11.5 Euthanasia Room Comforts
sect2.para: One of the duties of the technician during euthanasia is to ready the space where the procedure is taking place. Often this will be in the veterinary practice, either in rooms designated for euthanasia or in other rooms that can be used when necessary. Euthanasia may also take place outdoors or, as will be the case much of the time, in the patient’s home. Euthanasia may occur anywhere the patient and caregiver feel safe, and where the veterinary team can successfully complete the procedure. Occasionally there may be community restrictions on where euthanasia can be conducted, such as in public areas like parks and beaches.

emphasis.emphasis: There are several factors to consider when selecting a place for euthanasia, such as

listitem.para: Is the area quiet, private, and free of distractions?
Is it possible to transport the patient there with minimal stress?
Is the area large enough to accommodate everyone, with seating for all?
Can the patient lie down comfortably?
Will the temperature and lighting be appropriate?
Is there access to all supplies and equipment?
Will the space provide the caregiver with a meaningful goodbye to their pet?

sect3.title: 11.5.1 Euthanasia in the Hospital Setting
sect3.para: In the hospital setting, having a designated euthanasia room often referred to as a “Comfort Room” means there is a space always ready to receive patients and their families. Even if euthanasia appointment volume is low overall, having a designated room ready sends the right message that EOL services are important. This room can be used for quality‐of‐life discussions, palliative treatments, deceased pet viewing, and euthanasia. A comfort room exemplifies comfort, usually giving off a spa‐like feel where people and animals want to spend time (seeFigure 11.6).

figure.title:
Figure 11.6
Comfort room elements including seating and soft features. Source: Courtesy of CAETA.

textobject.phrase: A cozy living room features a brown sofa with a decorative pillow, a small side table, and a light lamp beside a chair.

sect3.para: Before the euthanasia appointment, a technician will enter the room to check that all items are prepared. This is an opportunity to reflect on what’s necessary for a successful appointment, catered specifically to the needs of everyone including the patient. For example, a large dog with mobility issues will benefit from a carpet runner to walk on. A fearful cat may be soothed by the application of pheromone sprays. A family with young children will appreciate a few toys and books placed in the room. While the room can be arranged with items specific to the needs of those entering it, it will also include fundamental elements such as:

listitem.para: Safety: nonslip flooring, pads to sit on, and just enough lighting to see what’s needed during the procedure.

Sensory: biophilic elements*, soothing sounds that drown out external noise, scents that manifest calm and relaxation, room temperature of 75 °F/24 °C or a little under, and soft things to touch such as pillows, blankets, and carpet/rugs.
Signals: markers just outside the room to notify staff that euthanasia is taking place, wireless doorbell alerts for caregivers to communicate with staff during times of privacy.
Spaciousness: room for loved ones to gather in comfort on the furniture or floor.

Supplies: everything kept in the room that would be needed to perform euthanasia and emotionally support caregivers, that is: injection supplies, potty pads, facial tissue, bottled water, and stethoscope.

sect3.para: *Biophilic elements: nature has a soothing presence and should be included in multiple locations within a veterinary hospital, including the comfort room. These include items such as quiet water features, plants, images of the natural world, and sounds of nature.

One of this author’s favorite euthanasia room features is a dry erase board set on a corner table or hung on the wall. The patient’s name is written on the board for family members to see (seeFigure 11.7). The technician may do this just before the appointment begins. At the close of the appointment, after the caregiver has left, the board is wiped clean as a symbolic gesture signifying death is complete. It may help veterinary staff compartmentalize the emotional nature of the work.

sect3.title: 11.5.2 Euthanasia in the Home Setting
sect3.para: Pet euthanasia in the home is considered by many to be the best location possible. This is in large part because it is believed that if the patient had a choice, home is where they themselves would want to be. A home provides so many of the comforts that veterinary hospitals try to emulate, and it is where animal hospice care is typically provided. Caregivers may have already made the choice to stop bringing their pets into hospitals for care, opting instead for all remaining medical support to be conducted at home. This includes the final medical procedure of euthanasia when it is necessary.

While the home has many features out of the control of technicians, they can still attend to multiple details to improve the euthanasia procedure. Technicians will often travel with veterinarians to the home and assist in all aspects of the appointment. One of the most important responsibilities is to make sure all supplies and equipment are ready. This includes enough needles, syringes, drugs, and preparatory supplies to ensure euthanasia can be done. Another important task is to check details such as the address, proper arrival time, where to park, and any special requests about how to enter the home (Pro Tip 11.2). Once there, technicians will establish rapport with caregivers and family pets, obtain consent to proceed with euthanasia, and prepare supplies for the procedure. Technicians may work with caregivers to determine the best location in the home (or outside) to gather, set the stage with adequate yet soft lighting, lay down blankets/towels for comfort, and quiet noisy distractions. Following euthanasia, technicians can collect all supplies and return them to the vehicle for safe return back to the hospital, including controlled substances. All of these features of a home appointment become even more important if the technician is the one performing euthanasia without a veterinarian onsite. While euthanasia is typically performed by a veterinarian, there are situations where animal suffering can be relieved more quickly by a technician performing euthanasia at the direction of the veterinarian. EOL care teams will take care to work within their region’s regulatory framework regarding scope of practice and controlled substance handling ch0023-c11-bib-0012. Where possible, mobilizing technicians to perform veterinarian‐directed euthanasia can significantly impact animal welfare and quality of dying. For example, a technician may be able to reach a hospice patient in distress and perform a preplanned, emergency home euthanasia much more quickly than the veterinarian already engaged in another urgent case.

listitem.para: Turn off vehicle music when approaching the home. Remove sunglasses.
Enter the home as a trusted friend.
Look for exit points and doorways that can accommodate stretchers for carrying large dogs out of the home.
Place a door hanger that indicates a private family event is in progress. Do not disturb (seeFigure 11.8).
Invite caregivers to turn off phones and quiet the room if appropriate.
Ensure everyone is gathered before proceeding.
Find a place to duck out of sight so the family may have privacy with their pet.
Remove all medical waste.
Drive away slowly with reverence, especially if the deceased patient is in the vehicle.
Leave behind a pet loss guide and other memorial items for the family.

sect2.title: 11.6 Balancing EOL Work and Well‐Being
sect2.para: Euthanasia, when conducted the right way, can be one of the most meaningful procedures in veterinary medicine. As common as euthanasia is, especially in animal hospice work, technicians will want to approach it with the mindset of helping, not hurting. Euthanasia that is chosen to relieve patient suffering can give technicians the feeling of doing good rather than doing harm. It is important that technicians believe that euthanasia is being done for the right reasons, and in the best way possible to create a lasting memory of love for caregivers. If technicians are in conflict with their morals, empathic strain and moral distress can set in. It is up to the entire veterinary team to ensure technicians find balance in EOL work. More information on empathic strain can be found inChapter 17.

Technicians can further care for their well‐being during euthanasia by calming their body before, during, and after euthanasia. Self‐regulation is a relaxation technique that lowers the body’s tension and quiets nervous energy. When technicians are more in control of their mind and body, they are less likely to experience secondary traumatic stress, also known as vicarious traumatizationch0023-c11-bib-0013. Secondary traumatic stress is one of the two main components of compassion fatigue ch0023-c11-bib-0014. The other is burnout, which results from too many demands on the job and not enough resources ch0023-c11-bib-0015. Euthanasia can be heavy with emotional trauma coming from caregivers, and often from the physical trauma of patients (e.g. hit by a car, uncontrollable seizures, or osteosarcoma fractures). Technicians who witness trauma in a relaxed state are less likely to internalize it. In other words, it is okay for a technician to accompany someone who is suffering, as long as the suffering does not become their own.

emphasis.emphasis: Tips to reduce secondary traumatic stress during euthanasia

listitem.para: Take deep breaths before entering the room.
Relax your pelvic muscles; release bodily tension.
Engage with the caregiver and patient with slow soothing movements and a mellow voice.
Listen to stories. It is ok to laugh and have moments of levity when appropriate.
Take deep sighs to dial back anxiety.
Provide soothing music and scents when appropriate.

emphasis.emphasis: Tips to reduce burnout during euthanasia

listitem.para: Recognize that euthanasia is the best course of action given the circumstances.
Support the caregiver with whatever they need.
Learn the best approach to techniques and feel prepared for any challenge that may present.
Perform a technically strong euthanasia.

sect2.para: Understanding how to deliver a perfect euthanasia experience will reduce anxiety during the procedure. Technicians can also use personal connections with caregivers and patients to help them relax. Witnessing the beauty of the human–animal bond during EOL care is a strong reminder of why veterinary professionals do what they do. Even though euthanasia can be emotionally challenging, focusing on the principles of the work should increase job fulfillment and compassion satisfaction.

listitem.para: Designate a technician to be with the caregiver and patient from start to finish.
Technicians should understand the basic methodology behind euthanasia techniques.
Pre‐euthanasia sedation and anesthesia are now the gold standard to induce sleep before death.
Euthanasia spaces should feel calm and relaxing.
Technicians achieve greater compassion satisfaction by providing meaningful euthanasia appointments.
